articles.headline: Prime Anchor: An Amazon Warehouse Town Dreams of a Better Life
articles.snippet: In Campbellsville, Ky., the tech giant’s influences abound. The profits, not so much.
articles.abstract: In Campbellsville, Ky., the tech giant’s influences abound. The profits, not so much.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAMPBELLSVILLE, Ky. — In the late 1990s, the town of Campbellsville in central Kentucky suffered a powerful jolt when its Fruit of the Loom textile plant closed. Thousands of jobs making underwear went to Central America, taking the community’s pride with them.

articles.headline: ‘Call Me Elizabeth’: Inside the Hours Elizabeth Warren Spends on the Phone
articles.snippet: She makes time to talk to kids, celebrities and state legislators. She’s not asking for money. She just wants to say hello — and to court good will.
articles.abstract: She makes time to talk to kids, celebrities and state legislators. She’s not asking for money. She just wants to say hello — and to court good will.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gideon Kidd of Cedar Falls is the driving force behind one of the larger social media megaphones in Iowa. He has built a following of more than 340,000 with his @IvePetThatDog Twitter account where he posts — truth in advertising — photos of himself petting dogs.

articles.headline: Congress Wants to Force Trump’s Hand on Human Rights in China and Beyond
articles.snippet: Lawmakers aim to pass veto-proof legislation in 2020 that would punish China over its treatment of ethnic Uighur Muslims.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers aim to pass veto-proof legislation in 2020 that would punish China over its treatment of ethnic Uighur Muslims.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a rare show of bipartisan unity, Republicans and Democrats are planning to try to force President Trump to take a more active stand on human rights in China, preparing veto-proof legislation that would punish top Chinese officials for detaining more than one million Muslims in internment camps.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong and Catie Edmondson

articles.headline: Inside America’s War Court: Clothing and Culture at Guantánamo Bay
articles.snippet: What the 9/11 case defendants, lawyers and others wear at the war court, like all fashion, has meaning. It evokes emotions, stirs controversy and, above all, sends messages.
articles.abstract: What the 9/11 case defendants, lawyers and others wear at the war court, like all fashion, has meaning. It evokes emotions, stirs controversy and, above all, sends messages.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.
articles.byline: By Carol Rosenberg and Wendy MacNaughton

articles.headline: Stocks Are on the Verge of the Best Year Since 1997
articles.snippet: Three Federal Reserve rate cuts and a rally in huge tech stocks like Apple have helped lift the S&P 500 by 29 percent so far in 2019.
articles.abstract: Three Federal Reserve rate cuts and a rally in huge tech stocks like Apple have helped lift the S&P 500 by 29 percent so far in 2019.
articles.lead_paragraph: The world is enmeshed in a trade war. The president has been impeached. The tech industry is under attack from regulators worldwide. But this year investors said: So what? The stock market is closing in on its best year in two decades. With only two days of trading to go, the S&P 500 could fare better than it has since 1997. Stock prices have been buoyed by a mere whiff of optimism that the economy — despite occasional hiccups and dire prognostications by so-called experts — will keep chugging along. And the Federal Reserve deserves credit, too, for cutting interest rates despite scowls from a White House that wanted more. So far this year, the S&P is up 29 percent. But the market crept up gradually as investors felt their way through the turbulent year, interrupted only by a handful of short-lived retreats. Since mid-October, stocks haven’t had a single daily gain of more than 1 percent. Even on Friday, the increase was tiny, but it left the index at a record and capped a fifth consecutive week of gains.

articles.headline: Somalia Bombing Kills Nearly 80, Raising Fears of Resurgent Militancy
articles.snippet: A truck filled with explosives blew up at a busy intersection in the capital. It was the latest, and the worst, in a series of recent attacks.
articles.abstract: A truck filled with explosives blew up at a busy intersection in the capital. It was the latest, and the worst, in a series of recent attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — An explosives-laden truck blew up at a busy intersection in the Somali capital on Saturday and killed at least 79 people, the latest sign of resurgent militant activity in a country plagued by an enduring strain of violent extremism.
articles.byline: By Hussein Mohamed, Abdi Latif Dahir and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: In China’s Crackdown on Muslims, Children Have Not Been Spared
articles.snippet: Nearly half a million children, many of them ethnic minorities, have been placed in boarding schools in Xinjiang where the authorities aim to instill loyalty to China and the Communist Party.
articles.abstract: Nearly half a million children, many of them ethnic minorities, have been placed in boarding schools in Xinjiang where the authorities aim to instill loyalty to China and the Communist Party.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOTAN, China — The first grader was a good student and beloved by her classmates, but she was inconsolable, and it was no mystery to her teacher why.

articles.headline: After ICE Raids, a Reckoning in Mississippi’s Chicken Country
articles.snippet: A series of federal immigration raids swept up nearly 700 undocumented workers, creating opportunities — and some ethical concerns — for American-born residents.
articles.abstract: A series of federal immigration raids swept up nearly 700 undocumented workers, creating opportunities — and some ethical concerns — for American-born residents.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Race affects our lives in countless ways. To read more provocative stories on race from The Times, sign up for our Race/Related newsletter here.]

articles.headline: ‘Nothing Less Than a Civil War’: These White Voters on the Far Right See Doom Without Trump
articles.snippet: Deeply conservative, they organize online and outside the Republican Party apparatus, engaging in more explicit versions of the chest-beating seen at the president’s rallies.
articles.abstract: Deeply conservative, they organize online and outside the Republican Party apparatus, engaging in more explicit versions of the chest-beating seen at the president’s rallies.
articles.lead_paragraph: GOLDEN VALLEY, Ariz. — Great American Pizza & Subs, on a highway about 100 miles southeast of Las Vegas, was busier and Trumpier than usual. On any given day it serves “M.A.G.A. Subs” and “Liberty Bell Lasagna.” The “Second Amendment” pizza comes “loaded” with pepperoni and sausage. The dining room is covered in regalia praising President Trump.

articles.headline: Inside the Biggest 2020 Advertising War Against Trump
articles.snippet: Michael Bloomberg’s presidential campaign wants to flood voters with attacks on Mr. Trump before it is too late, a lesson Republican candidates learned in 2016 when they initially ignored him.
articles.abstract: Michael Bloomberg’s presidential campaign wants to flood voters with attacks on Mr. Trump before it is too late, a lesson Republican candidates learned in 2016 when they initially ignored him.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hillary Clinton tried. So did 16 rival Republicans. And after hundreds of millions of dollars were spent on ads attacking Donald Trump in 2016, the results were the same: They never did much damage.

articles.headline: What Does California’s New Data Privacy Law Mean? Nobody Agrees
articles.snippet: The statute was meant to standardize how companies disclose their consumer data-mining practices. So far, not so much.
articles.abstract: The statute was meant to standardize how companies disclose their consumer data-mining practices. So far, not so much.
articles.lead_paragraph: Millions of people in California are now seeing notices on many of the apps and websites they use. “Do Not Sell My Personal Information,” the notices may say, or just “Do Not Sell My Info.”

articles.headline: For China’s Pickup Artists, Sex Is the Goal and Urging Suicide Is a Tactic
articles.snippet: In China, teaching men the manipulative ways of the pickup artist became big business. A crackdown is revealing a curriculum of abuse.
articles.abstract: In China, teaching men the manipulative ways of the pickup artist became big business. A crackdown is revealing a curriculum of abuse.
articles.lead_paragraph: “You’ve given your best thing to another man,” he texted her, referring to her virginity. “I’m left with nothing.”

articles.headline: California Is Booming. Why Are So Many Californians Unhappy?
articles.snippet: Fire, garbage and homelessness increasingly plague the Golden State.
articles.abstract: Fire, garbage and homelessness increasingly plague the Golden State.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Christine Johnson, a public-finance consultant with an engineering degree, was running for a seat on the San Francisco Board of Supervisors.

articles.headline: Behind the Ukraine Aid Freeze: 84 Days of Conflict and Confusion
articles.snippet: The inside story of President Trump’s demand to halt military assistance to an ally shows the price he was willing to pay to carry out his agenda.
articles.abstract: The inside story of President Trump’s demand to halt military assistance to an ally shows the price he was willing to pay to carry out his agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Deep into a long flight to Japan aboard Air Force One with President Trump, Mick Mulvaney, the acting White House chief of staff, dashed off an email to an aide back in Washington.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton, Maggie Haberman and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Left Behind by Migrant Husbands, Women Break the Rules and Go to Work
articles.snippet: Wives are shocking their traditional West African villages by earning money and running large households while their husbands are in Europe seeking jobs.
articles.abstract: Wives are shocking their traditional West African villages by earning money and running large households while their husbands are in Europe seeking jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: KOUTIA, Senegal — Years had passed since her husband had crossed the sea to look for work in Europe. Left behind, Khadijah Diagouraga trudged to the couple’s peanut fields alone every day, struggling to earn enough to provide for an extended family of 13.
articles.byline: By Dionne Searcey and Laura Boushnak

articles.headline: A 7-Eleven in Japan Might Close for a Day. Yes, That’s a Big Deal.
articles.snippet: In a dispute captivating a country of workaholics, Mitoshi Matsumoto says the company is threatening to rescind his franchise after he complained about draconian work hours.
articles.abstract: In a dispute captivating a country of workaholics, Mitoshi Matsumoto says the company is threatening to rescind his franchise after he complained about draconian work hours.
articles.lead_paragraph: HIGASHI-OSAKA, Japan — Mitoshi Matsumoto, the most famous 7-Eleven convenience store owner in Japan, wants to do something unthinkable in his 24-hour, 7-day-a-week industry: take a day off.
articles.byline: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno

articles.headline: After Another Year of Trump Attacks, ‘Ominous Signs’ for the American Press
articles.snippet: Threats of ‘retribution,’ more accusations of ‘fake news’ and the end of the White House briefing made 2019 the darkest yet for journalists in the Trump era.
articles.abstract: Threats of ‘retribution,’ more accusations of ‘fake news’ and the end of the White House briefing made 2019 the darkest yet for journalists in the Trump era.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Twitter, President Trump deployed the phrase “fake news” 273 times this year — 50 percent more often than he did in 2018. He demanded “retribution” over a “Saturday Night Live” sketch, declared that Washington Post reporters “shouldn’t even be allowed on the grounds of the White House,” and accused The New York Times of “Treason.”

articles.headline: How Big Companies Won New Tax Breaks From the Trump Administration
articles.snippet: As the Treasury Department prepared to enact the 2017 Republican tax overhaul, corporate lobbyists swarmed — and won big.
articles.abstract: As the Treasury Department prepared to enact the 2017 Republican tax overhaul, corporate lobbyists swarmed — and won big.
articles.lead_paragraph: The overhaul of the federal tax law in 2017 was the signature legislative achievement of Donald J. Trump’s presidency.
articles.byline: By Jesse Drucker and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Inside China’s Push to Turn Muslim Minorities Into an Army of Workers
articles.snippet: The Communist Party wants to remold Xinjiang’s minorities into loyal blue-collar workers to supply Chinese factories with cheap labor.
articles.abstract: The Communist Party wants to remold Xinjiang’s minorities into loyal blue-collar workers to supply Chinese factories with cheap labor.
articles.lead_paragraph: KASHGAR, China — The order from Chinese officials was blunt and urgent. Villagers from Muslim minorities should be pushed into jobs, willing or not. Quotas would be set and families penalized if they refused to go along.
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley and Austin Ramzy
